An important clarification, the secretion of ACTH from the anterior pituitary gland does NOT stimulate the production of epinephrine like they say it does in the video. ACTH only targets the zona fasciculata and the zona reticularis regions of the anterior pituitary glands, resulting in the secretion of ONLY cortisol and sex steroid hormones. Still provides a great overview, but if you are using this as a resource for an exam just know that epinephrine comes from the medulla region of the adrenal glands!

Epinephrine/adrenaline release from the adrenal glands during a 'fight or flight' situation isn't mediated by ACTH (this would take far too long for it to be effective). The message comes via the sympathetic nervous system which directly innervates the adrenal medulla. Once a dangerous situation is detected by the brain, impulses travel through the SNS straight to the adrenal medulla which then releases a heap of adrenaline into the bloodstream. Resulting in an almost immeadiate response - increased heart rate/respiration rate/blood pressure, dilation of the pupils etc.

I want to make a really important distinction that wasn't made in the video. An Exocrine gland is not synonymous for "secretions outside of the body." An Exocrine gland is a gland that secretes through a duct, which yes, primarily includes secretion to the outside of the body like sweat and salivary glands, but it also includes glands that secrete inside of the gut, such as the pancreas secreting enzymes into the lumen of the small intestine. Don't let that trick question on the exam throw you off! ;)

Belal El-Baba Close. Noradrenaline (aka: norepinephrine) is a closely-related compound that acts a lot like adrenaline. In fact, they bind to the same receptors and have similar actions on target cells. Noradrenaline is released very rapidly by the sympathetic nervous system as part of the "fight or flight" response to stress. Within minutes, stress also triggers the release of adrenaline (and a little more noradrenaline) from the adrenal gland.

Snorre Grimstad The hypothalamus pretty much tells the pituitary what to do. There's a special set of blood vessels that connect the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary. The hypothalamus releases very tiny amounts of hormone into those specialized vessels and they travel directly to the anterior pituitary, either stimulating or inhibiting the release of pituitary hormones.

ACTH - would not actually cause the release of epinephrine; it would cause the release of adrenal cortex hormones, e.g. Cortisol and Aldestoreone. Epinephrine and norepinephrine are released from the adrenal medulla when it is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system (neural stimuli) when the body is experiencing short term stress (exercise - anxiety - shock). Which brings to the next point - Glucagon is mainly released to maintain homeostatic range of blood-glucose levels when an individual is fasting. When an individual is doing "push-ups" this triggers the short term stress response - by the sympathetic nervous - and thus the key hormones in this situation would actually be epinephrine and norepinephrine - which stimulate glycogenolysis and gluconeogenisis (amongst other things) thus increasing blood - glucose levels for muscle cells

Good video, but I noticed one mistake.  The video defined exocrine glands as glands that "send stuff outside of the body" (1:34)  Glands are organized arrangements of secretory cells.   Exocrine glands are glands that have ducts, while endocrine glands are ductless. Endocrine glands release hormones directly into blood and lymph, while exocrine glands secrete their products into a duct leading to an epithelial surface (inside or outside body). Example of endocrine glands- many glands in digestive system i.e., the liver and the pancreas contain both endocrine and exocrine cells.  In the pancreas, exocrine cells secrete hydrolytic digestive enzymes into duct connected to duodenum. Endocrine cells in the pancreas secrete glucagon, insulin and somatostatin directly into the bloodstream.  In the liver, exocrine cells secrete bile into ducts connected to the  gall bladder

Even If endocrine glands are concerned, Thyroid Gland is the largest gland .  The pancreas, weighing between 85 to 150 g (adult), is a large elongated gland (12~15 cm long; 3~4 cm wide; 1.5~2.5 cm thick) located behind the stomach. It has both endocrine and exocrine functions. It secretes digestive enzymes and sodium bicarbonate into the duodenum and secretes hormones into the blood.   The liver (25 cm long; 15 cm wide) is a reddest brown gland located immediately inferior to the diaphragm, filling most of the right hypochondriac and epigastric regions. It has a tremendous variety of functions. One of the liver's exocrine functions is the secretion of bile that contributes to digestion. In that sense, the liver is considered the body's largest gland, weighing about 1.4 kg

Adrenaline (a.k.a. epinepherine, although many people use the term adrenaline to colloquially refer to norepinepherine as well) is not instantaneous.  The instantaneous response that is felt is due to the actions of the nervous system: the central nervous system (i.e. brain), and the sympathetic and parasympathetic aspects of the peripheral nervous system are all involved.  Neurotransmitters are responsible for the immediate effect, while adrenaline may take anywhere from 15-60 seconds.

The "glands" that become swollen when sick aren't true glands in the medical sense (i.e. they aren't part of the endocrine system, nor do they secrete hormones).  Swollen "glands" are actually lymph nodes, which are part of the immune system, and are responsible for producing antibodies and generally helping to coordinate the body's response to infection.

Great video! But there's a mistake on it... ACTH doesn't stimulate the production of epinefrine. As the name suggests, ACTH - Adrenocorticotropic Hormone stimulates the cortex of the adrenal gland, where mineralcorticoids and glucocorticoids are produced, being the main one, cortisol. The release of epinefrine is regulated mainly by the autonomous nervous system and it happens on the medulla of the gland.  Sorry for my poor English :P
